conclusion: Analyze the behavior of gases in the chambers as the piston moves upwards to determine when gas starts to leak.
Initially, both chambers have the same volume V, pressure p, and temperature T. Total volume is 2V and height is 2H.
As the piston moves upwards, the volume of the lower chamber increases and the upper chamber decreases. V0 + V1 = 2V.
Pressure in each chamber changes due to volume change. Using PV = nRT, P0 V0 = PV and P1 V1 = PV.
Solve for P0 and P1: P0 = PV/V0 and P1 = PV/V1.
Diaphragm moves when net force is zero: P0 A - P1 A - mg = 0, leading to (P0 - P1) A = mg.
Substitute P0 and P1: (PV/V0 - PV/V1) A = mg, leading to PV (1/V0 - 1/V1) A = mg.
Simplify using V1 = 2V - V0: PV ((2V - V0) - V0)/(V0 (2V - V0)) A = mg.
Further simplify: PV (2(V - V0))/(V0 (2V - V0)) A = mg.
Solve for V0: 2PV (V - V0)/(V0 (2V - V0)) = mg/A.
Substitute mg/A = mgH/V: 2PV (V - V0)/(V0 (2V - V0)) = mgH/V.
Rearrange: 2PV^2 V - 2PV^2 V0 = mgH V0 (2V - V0).
Further rearrange: 2PV^2 V = mgH V0 (2V - V0) + 2PV^2 V0.
Solve for V0: V0 = 2PV^2 V/(mgH (2V - V0) + 2PV^2).
Volume of the lower chamber V0 when gas starts to leak is 2V/(1 + x).
